context: DNAPL source zones both in the Birmingham aquifer (Rivett et al., 2005) and more generally (Pankow and Cherry, 1996) are likely to persistently produce plumes over decade and longer timeframes. It is hence surmised that most temporal changes were introduced by either groundwater flow direction variability due to short-term or seasonal water-level changes and associated transients in the mixing zone (Ellis et al., 2007-this issue; later Fig. 5d chloride data) rather than transient contaminant source-zone inputs.Natural attenuation Fraction of organic carbon (f oc) data (15 riverbed core samples) indicated retardation due to sorption was towards 1–2 orders of magnitude greater in the hyporheic zone sediments than the underlying Triassic sandstones. Riverbed f oc ranged from 0.0008 to 0.092 with a mean of 0.011 (Ellis, 2003) compared to a mean f oc of 0.00049 for the Birmingham Triassic sandstone (Shepherd, 2002). Based upon a literature geometric mean K oc (organic-carbon partition coefficient) for TCE of 94 ml/g (USEPA, 1996), TCE retardation factors (R) were estimated at 1.3 for the sandstone and 8.8 for the mean riverbed and 66 for the maximum riverbed f oc values. These estimates assume that standard hydrophobic partitioning theory and equilibrium sorption applies with R estimated from: (1) R = 1 + ( ρ n ) f oc K oc where ρ and n are the dry bulk density and porosity of the porous media respectively taking the values 1.96 g/ml and 0.26 respectively in all calculations. These are mean values for the West Midlands sandstone (Allen et al., 1997), but also taken as a representative mean of the riverbed deposits (for which porosity data were not obtained). Sorption data were insufficient to conclude upon any correlations present between f oc (sorption) and grain-size (hydraulic conductivity) thereby allowing more accurate predictions of sorption-modified travel times through the hyporheic zone.
